pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.1: The nuns’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:3.1: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:6.1: Venerables, these one hundred and sixty-six rules on offenses entailing confession come up for recitation.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:7.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:7.2: At that time a lay disciple had invited the Order of nuns to ask for garlic:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:7.3: “If any of the nuns need garlic, I’ll supply it.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:7.4: And he had told his field-keeper,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:7.5: “If the nuns come, give two or three bulbs to each nun.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:7.6: On that occasion a festival was being held in Sāvatthī,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:7.7: and the garlic was used up as soon as it arrived there.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:7.8: Just then the nuns went to that lay follower and said,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:7.11: As soon as the garlic arrives, it’s used up.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:7.13: The nun Thullanandā went to the field, and not having any sense of moderation she took a large amount of garlic.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:7.14: The field-keeper complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:7.15: “How could the nuns not have any sense of moderation and take a large amount of garlic?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:8.1: The nuns heard the complaints of that field-keeper,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:8.2: and the nuns of few desires complained and criticized her,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:8.3: “How could Venerable Thullanandā not have any sense of moderation and take a large amount of garlic?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:8.4: “Is it true, monks, that the nun Thullanandā did this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:8.7: “How could the nun Thullanandā not have any sense of moderation and take a large amount of garlic?
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:8.8: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:8.9: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:9.2: “At one time, monks, Thullanandā was the wife of a brahmin.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:9.5: Then, when that brahmin had died, he was reborn as a goose.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:9.6: His feathers were all made of gold,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:9.7: and he gave them one feather at a time.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:9.8: After thinking about this, Thullanandā took hold of that king of geese and plucked him.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:9.9: But when his feathers regrew they were white.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:9.10: At that time, monks, Thullanandā lost her gold because of too much greed.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:9.11: Now she will lose her garlic.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:10.1: One should be content with what one gets,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:10.3: After taking hold of the king of geese,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:10.4: The gold came to an end.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:11.1: Then, after criticizing the nun Thullanandā in many ways for being difficult to support …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:11.2: the Master said, “And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:12.1: ‘If a nun eats garlic, she commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:13.4: … The nun who has been given the full ordination by both complete Orders through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:14.2: from Magadha is what is meant.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:15.1: If she receives it with the intention of eating it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:15.2: For every mouthful, she commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:16.1: If it is garlic and she perceives it as garlic, and she eats it, she commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:16.2: If it is garlic, but she is unsure if it is, and she eats it, she commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:16.3: If it is garlic, but she does not perceive it as garlic, and she eats it, she commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:17.1: If it is not garlic, but she perceives it as garlic, and she eats it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:17.2: If it is not garlic, but she is unsure of it, and she eats it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:17.3: If it is not garlic and she does not perceive it as garlic, and she eats it, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:18.12: if she is the first offender.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:19.1: The first rule, the training rule on garlic, is finished.
